place_detail.name: location_type
place_detail.label: I am a landowner in Kittitas County

fields.name: large_fires_header
fields.content:
Kittitas County:

a Fire Environment

fields.name: private-landowner_email
fields.placeholder: Your email address will never be shared
fields.prompt: Enter your email address to make sure you get information about an onsite wildfire consultation at the end of this survey. You'll learn about your wildfire risk and forest conditions:

fields.name: large_fires_information
fields.content:
Kittitas County is in the heart of fire-prone country. 36 large fires have burned here since 1973.

Click on fires on the map to learn more about them, and use the slider in the lower left to explore the changing wildfire risk in central Washington.

Large wildfires in Kittitas County
Large wildfires elsewhere in Washington
36Large wildfires started since 1973227,533Total acres burned

fields.name: forest_type
fields.prompt: On your land, which forest type is predominant? (See below for descriptions and images of forest types.)

fields.name: forest_type_information
fields.content:
Subalpine: Subalpine fir generally occupies colder, higher elevation mountain forests. Fires are typically stand-replacing events at approximately 200-year or greater intervals. When wildfire occurs, this forest is more susceptible to high intensity crown fires.

Fire return interval200+ years

Moist Mix Conifer: Forests of grand fir, white fir, and Douglas-fir with an average fire return interval of 45-100 years. When wildfire occurs in this forest type it can vary from medium to high severity.

Fire return interval45-100 years

Dry Forest: A forest dominated by ponderosa pine, with understory conifers like Douglas Fir and Grand Fir. Lack of wildfire can result in dense stands highly susceptible to medium to high intensity fires. The wildfire return intervals are 15-25 years.

Fire return interval15-25 years

Ponderosa Pine: Straddles the line between rangelands and forest with an overstory of ponderosa pine trees and an understory of shrubs, grasses, and forbs. Wildfires were historically common in this forest type, with return intervals of 8-15 years.

Fire return interval8-15 years

Non-forest Rangeland: Rangeland (shrub steppe with sagebrush and grasses) with fire intervals of 5-15 years. When wildfire occurs in this land cover type, the severity is dependent on the vegetation density and weather (wind-driven).

Fire return interval5-15 years

fields.name: fire_risk_information
fields.content:
Wildfire risk varies throughout Kittitas County. The probability of wildfire is based on historical fires, vegetation and public safety.

Severe risk

Low risk

This map shows general wildfire probability. Wind-blown embers generated during wildfires are the single biggest hazard wildfires pose to homes. Look at the risk level not just where your home is located but at least in a one mile radius to better understand your risk from these burning pieces of airborne wood and/or vegetation.

This map also shows large wildfires and individual wildfire start sites from the last several years. Click on a start site to learn more about it.

fields.name: fire_resources_header
fields.content: Kittitas County Fire Resources

fields.name: private-address
fields.placeholder: Your address will never be shared

fields.name: fire_resources_information
fields.content:
Kittitas County has numerous fire resources you should be aware of, including fire districts and Firewise USA communities.

Search for your address above (or zoom and scroll the map) to explore resources in your area.

If you know your tax parcel number but not your address, go to https://gis.co.kittitas.wa.us/compas/default.aspx and enter your parcel number to find more information including the "situs" address.

If your property resides in a fire district, it does not guarantee that the fire district or fire department will be able to defend your property during a wildfire event.

fields.name: landowner_confidence
fields.prompt: How do you feel about your answers to list of tasks in the area around your home?

content.label: Im very confident that Ive taken the actions that reduce my risk in a wildfire
Im somewhat confident that Ive taken the actions that reduce my risk in a wildfire
Ive completed some of these actions, but have many left to do
Im overwhelmed by the list of actions and concerned about my property and my neighborhood

fields.name: not_completed_reasons
fields.prompt: If you have not completed some of the tasks, why not? (check all that apply)

content.label: I didnt know they were important to reducing my risk
I am not able to do the work myself
I cant afford to have the work done

fields.name: interested_assistance
fields.prompt: There are people and programs here to help you with assessing your property, determining next steps and securing grants to help with the financial burden of completing work. Just let us know what you need

content.label: Im interested in technical advice on what my home and property need
Im interested in learning more about available financial assistance

fields.prompt: Add any additional comments about your wildfire preparedness efforts
fields.label: Comment

fire_resiliency_information.content:
Be resilient! As a landowner in a fire environment, what you do (and don't do!) on your property matters.

Tell us a bit about your property and practices, and we'll send you a customized report with fire resiliency resources and other information.

We'll ask about your fire resiliency practices in three zones around your property:

  • Immediate Zone: 0 - 5 feet from house
  • Intermediate Zone: 5 - 30 feet from house
  • Extended Zone: 30 - 100 feet from house

immediate_zone_information.content: The immediate zone extends to 5 feet from your house. This zone is the most vulnerable to embers. Start here with your fire resiliency efforts.

intermediate_zone_information.content: The intermediate zone extends between 5 and 30 feet from your house. In this zone, using careful landscaping or hardscaping techniques to create fuel breaks can help decrease fire behavior.

extended_zone_information.content: From your home, this zone extends out 30 to 100 feet or even 200 feet if on a slope. The goal here is not to eliminate fire but to interrupt fires path and keep flames smaller and on the ground.

clean_roofs.prompt: I clean roofs and gutters of dead leaves, debris and pine needles that could catch embers and I keep my roof in good repair.
clean_roofs.label: Clean roofs and gutters

replace_shingles.prompt: I replace or repair any loose or missing shingles or roof tiles to prevent ember penetration
replace_shingles.label: Replace or repair loose shingles

reduce_embers.prompt: I reduce embers that could pass through vents by installing 1/8 inch metal mesh screening on foundations and/or exterior attic vents.
reduce_embers.label: Reduce embers

clean_debris_attic_vents.prompt: I clean debris from exterior attic vents and install 1/8 inch metal mesh screening to reduce embers
clean_debris_attic_vents.label: Clean debris from attic vents

repair_screens.prompt: Ive screened in areas below patios and decks with wire mesh to prevent debris and combustible materials from accumulating
repair_screens.label: Repair or replace window screens

move_flammable_material.prompt: Ive moved any flammable material away from wall exteriors--mulch, flammable plants, leaves and needles, firewood piles--anything that can burn as well as anything stored underneath decks or porches.
move_flammable_material.label: Move flammable material

clear_vegetation.prompt: I clear vegetation from under and in a 5-foot perimeter around my propane tank
clear_vegetation.label: Clear vegetation from propane tanks

create_fuel_breaks.prompt: Ive created fuel breaks with driveways, walkways/paths, patios, and decks
create_fuel_breaks.label: Create fuel breaks

mow_to_four_inches.prompt: I keep lawns and native grasses mowed to a height of four inches
mow_to_four_inches.label: Keep lawns mowed to four inches

remove_ladder_fuels.prompt: I prune tree limbs so the lowest branches are 6 to 10 feet above the ground to help reduce the chance of fire getting into the crowns of the trees
remove_ladder_fuels.label: Remove ladder fuels

space_trees.prompt: I space trees to have a minimum of 18 feet between crowns, with the distance increasing with the percentage of slope
space_trees.label: Space trees to eighteen feet

tree_placement.prompt: I ensure that mature tree canopy is no closer than ten feet to the edge of any structures on my property
tree_placement.label: Keep tree canopy ten feet from structures

small_tree_clusters.prompt: I ensure that trees and shrubs in the intermediate zone are limited to small clusters of a few each to break up the continuity of vegetation
small_tree_clusters.label: Break up continuity of vegetation

dispose_ground_debris.prompt: I dispose of heavy accumulations of ground litter and debris
dispose_ground_debris.label: Dispose of ground debris

remove_dead_material.prompt: I regularly remove dead plant and tree material
remove_dead_material.label: Remove dead plant material

remove_small_conifers.prompt: I remove small conifers growing between mature trees
remove_small_conifers.label: Remove small conifers between mature trees

remove_outbuilding_vegetation.prompt: I remove vegetation adjacent to storage sheds or other outbuildings
remove_outbuilding_vegetation.label: Remove adjacent outbuilding vegetation

space_canopy_tops_30_60_feet.prompt: I ensure that trees 30 to 60 feet from the home have at least 12 feet between canopy tops
space_canopy_tops_30_60_feet.label: Space canopy tops 30 to 60 feet from the house

space_canopy_tops_60_100_feet.prompt: I ensure that trees 60 to 100 feet from the home have at least 6 feet between the canopy tops
space_canopy_tops_60_100_feet.label: Space canopy tops 60 to 100 feet from the house

evacuation_plan.prompt: I have an evacuation plan that includes escape routes (preferably 2), a designated family meeting location, and a communication plan
evacuation_plan.label: Evacuation plan

emergency_kit_supplies.prompt: I have an emergency kit prepared with water, food, clothes, flashlight, first aid kit, etc.
emergency_kit_supplies.label: Food and water

documents.prompt: I have my important family documents, bank and credit card information, identification, prescriptions, etc. in one location easily accessible during an evacuation
documents.label: Copies of documents

evacuation_plan_pets.prompt: I have an evacuation plan for my pets, large animals or livestock
evacuation_plan_pets.label: Evacuation plan

emergency_notifications.prompt: Ive signed up for the emergency notification system through the Kittitas County Sheriffs Office or I know where to go for official information
emergency_notifications.label: Food and water

content: The Kittitas County Fire Adapted program is designed to educate landowners and others about wildfire risk in their communities, and about how to prepare for the next wildfire.
